questions.question: Which command displays free disk space for mounted filesystems in human-readable units?

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the command foo 1> bar?
answers: The stdout from the command foo is appended to the file bar.
The stdout from the command foo overwrites the file bar.
The command foo receives its stdin from the file bar.
The command foo receives its stdin from the stdout of the command bar.
The stderr from the command foo is saved to the file bar.
questions.explanation: 1> redirects stdout, overwriting the file

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding hard links?
answers: A hard link can span different filesystems.
A hard link can be created for a directory.
A hard link points to the same inode as the original file.
A hard link can be created for a symbolic link.
A hard link increases file size
questions.explanation: Hard links point to the same inode, sharing the same data blocks

questions.question: Which RPM command will output the name of the package which supplied the file /etc/exports?
questions.explanation: rpm -qf reports the package owning a file

questions.question: Which sed command replaces all occurrences of 'insane' with 'to drink' in printer.txt?
questions.explanation: The 'g' flag makes the replacement global (all occurrences on each line)

questions.question: Which signal is missing from the following command that is commonly used to instruct a daemon to reinitialize itself, including reading configuration files?
questions.explanation: SIGHUP causes daemons to reinitialize/read config

questions.question: Which tar option creates an archive using xz compression?
questions.explanation: The -J option uses xz compression

questions.question: Which utility would be used to change how often a filesystem check is performed on an ext2 filesystem without losing any data stored on that filesystem?
questions.explanation: tune2fs configures check frequency safely

questions.question: Which variable defines the directories in which a Bash shell searches for executable commands?
questions.explanation: PATH specifies directories searched for commands

questions.question: A company's IT associate has been asked to switch to single-user mode on a running Linux server in order to perform some troubleshooting. Of the options below, which is the best way of doing this?
questions.explanation: Use init 1 on SysV-style systems to reach runlevel 1, on systemd systems prefer systemctl isolate rescue.target to switch to singleâ€‘user/rescue mode.

questions.question: The command chmod u+wx file.txt will:
answers: Add write and execute permissions for the user (owner) of the file.
Remove read permissions for the user.
Add write and execute permissions for all users.
Change the ownership of the file.
questions.explanation: Adds write and execute permissions for the file owner only (u+wx modifies user/owner bits).

questions.question: The command df is primarily used to:
questions.explanation: df reports filesystem disk space usage (total, used, available) for mounted filesystems.

questions.question: The octal permission mode 0755 corresponds to which set of permissions?
answers: Owner: rwx, Group: r-x, Others: r-x
Owner: rw-, Group: r--, Others: r--
Owner: r-x, Group: r-x, Others: r-x
Owner: rwx, Group: rwx, Others: rwx
questions.explanation: 0755 = owner rwx (7), group r-x (5), others r-x (5) â†’ rwxr-xr-x.

questions.question: Which command changes the owner (user and/or group) of a file?
questions.explanation: Use chown user:group file to change owner and group. chgrp changes only group, chmod adjusts permissions.

questions.question: Which command is used to create a new directory?
questions.explanation: mkdir is the standard command to create directories.

questions.question: Which command is used to display the current working directory's full path?
questions.explanation: pwd prints the absolute pathname of the current directory.

questions.question: Which command is used to find a specific text string within a file?
questions.explanation: grep 'pattern' file searches file contents, find searches filenames/attributes.

questions.question: Which command is used to remove files permanently in Linux?
questions.explanation: rm deletes files (permanently). rmdir removes empty directories.

questions.question: Which command is used to update the package index on Debian-based Linux systems like Ubuntu?
questions.explanation: apt-get update (or apt update) refreshes the package index on Debian/Ubuntu systems.

questions.question: Which command is used to view the Linux kernel version running on your system?
questions.explanation: uname -r prints the currently running kernel release string.

questions.question: Which command prints the absolute pathname of the current working directory?
questions.explanation: pwd outputs the absolute pathname of the current directory.

questions.question: Which command schedules a one-time job to run at a specific time in the future?
questions.explanation: The at command schedules a one-time job,  cron is for recurring jobs.

questions.question: Which command searches the filesystem hierarchy starting at the specified directory for files matching a name pattern?
questions.explanation: find / -name 'pattern' searches the directory tree for filenames matching the pattern.

questions.question: Which command shows the last 50 lines of /var/log/syslog and continues printing new lines as the file grows?
questions.explanation: tail -n 50 -f shows the last 50 lines and follows appended output in real time.

questions.question: Which commands display disk usage? (Select two)
questions.explanation: df -h reports filesystem usage,  du -sh reports disk usage for directories/files.

questions.question: Which package manager is the default for Debian and Ubuntu families for installing and removing packages?
questions.explanation: Debian/Ubuntu use apt (front-end to dpkg) for package management.

questions.question: Which statement correctly distinguishes a hard link from a symbolic link (symlink)?
answers: A hard link points to the same inode, a symlink is a special file containing a pathname.
A hard link stores the target pathname, a symlink points directly to the inode.
Hard links only work for directories, symlinks only work for files.
questions.explanation: Hard links can cross filesystems, symlinks cannot. A hard link is another directory entry referencing the same inode, a symlink is a separate file that holds a pathname to the target.

questions.question: What are the three basic types of file permissions in Linux?
questions.explanation: Linux file permissions are read (r), write (w) and execute (x), these apply to user, group and others.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the setgid bit on a directory?
answers: Forces files to inherit the directory's group ownership
Sets file timestamps to current time
questions.explanation: setgid ensures new files and subdirectories inherit the group of the parent directory

questions.question: Which of the following commands can be used to display the current running processes on the system?
questions.explanation: top, htop, and ps display running processes with different formats and features

questions.question: Which of the following commands can be used to display the current system date and time?
questions.explanation: date shows date/time, timedatectl manages system time settings

questions.question: Which of the following commands can be used to display the disk space usage of file systems?
questions.explanation: df shows filesystem disk space usage, du shows directory/file space usage

questions.question: Which of the following commands can be used to display the last lines of a text file?
questions.explanation: tail shows last lines, less and more are pagers that can navigate through files

questions.question: A Linux administrator needs to identify the kernel version of the Linux operating system they are currently using. Which command should they execute?
questions.explanation:
The command uname -r is used in Linux to display the kernel version of the operating system. It specifically shows the release number of the kernel.
Option B is incorrect.
lsb_release -a displays the Linux Standard Base (LSB) and distribution-specific information, but not the kernel version.
Option C is incorrect.
cat /etc/os-release shows information about the Linux distribution but does not display the kernel version.
Option D is incorrect.
ifconfig is a command used for displaying and configuring network interfaces, and it is unrelated to displaying the kernel version.

questions.question: A Linux administrator wants to monitor real-time system processes and their resource usage. Which command should they use?
questions.explanation:
The top command is used in Linux for real-time monitoring of system processes and their resource usage, including CPU and memory. It provides a dynamic, real-time view of a running system.
Option A is incorrect.
ps displays information about a selection of active processes, but it does not provide real-time, continuously updated information like top.
Option B is incorrect.
df (disk free) is used to report the amount of disk space used and available on file systems, not for monitoring system processes.
Option D is incorrect.
chmod changes the file access permissions but is not related to monitoring system processes or resource usage.

questions.question: A Linux system administrator needs to display a tree-like structure of all running processes. Which command should they use?
questions.explanation:
The pstree command displays running processes as a tree, which is particularly useful for showing the hierarchy and parent-child relationships between processes.
Option A is incorrect.
ps aux lists all running processes with detailed information, but it does not display them in a tree-like structure.
Option B is incorrect.
top provides a dynamic real-time view of running processes, focusing on resource usage, but not in a tree structure.
Option D is incorrect.
ifconfig is used for configuring network interfaces and has no relation to process management.

questions.question: A Linux system administrator wants to display the amount of time since the system was last booted. Which command should they use?
questions.explanation:
The uptime command shows how long the system has been running since the last boot, along with the current time, the number of users currently logged in, and the system load averages.
Option B is incorrect.
last is used to show a listing of last logged in users, not the system uptime since the last boot.
Option C is incorrect.
While top provides real-time information about system processes and resource usage, it does not specifically display the system uptime since the last boot.
Option D is incorrect.
date displays the current system date and time, but it does not provide information on the system uptime.

questions.question: A Linux user needs to copy a directory named data and all its contents to a new location. Which command should they use?
questions.explanation:
The cp -r command is used to copy a directory and all of its contents, including subdirectories and files, to a new location. In this scenario, cp -r data /new/location will copy the data directory to /new/location.
Option B is incorrect.
mv is used to move files or directories from one location to another, not for copying.
Option C is incorrect.
ls -R data > /new/location will list all files and directories recursively but will not copy them to the new location.
Option D is incorrect.
mkdir /new/location/data simply creates a new directory and does not copy the contents of the existing data directory.

questions.question: A Linux user needs to create an empty file named log.txt in their current directory. Which command should they use?
questions.explanation:
The touch command is used in Linux to create a new empty file. Using touch log.txt will create an empty file named log.txt in the current directory.
Option B is incorrect.
mkdir is used to create a new directory, not an empty file.
Option C is incorrect.
cp is used to copy files and directories, and it requires both a source and a destination, it cannot be used to create a new file.
Option D is incorrect.
rm is used to remove files and directories, not to create them.

questions.question: A Linux user wants to display the amount of time since the system was last booted. Which command should they use?
questions.explanation:
The uptime command shows how long the system has been running since the last boot, along with the current time, the number of users currently logged in, and the system load averages.
Option B is incorrect.
last is used to show a listing of last logged in users, not the system uptime since the last boot.
Option C is incorrect.
While top provides real-time information about system processes and resource usage, it does not specifically display the system uptime since the last boot.
Option D is incorrect.
date displays the current system date and time, but it does not provide information on the system uptime.

questions.question: A Linux user wants to view detailed system information, including hardware, kernel version, and environment variables. Which command should they use?
questions.explanation:
The uname -a command in Linux displays all system information, including the kernel version, hostname, kernel release date, processor type, and more. It is a comprehensive command for system information.
Option B is incorrect.
top is used for real-time system monitoring, including process activity and system resource usage, but it does not display detailed hardware and environment information.
Option C is incorrect.
env displays environment variables. While it provides information about the user environment, it does not show detailed system information like hardware or kernel version.
Option D is incorrect.
lscpu displays CPU architecture information, but it does not provide comprehensive system information including kernel version or environment variables.

questions.question: A system administrator is tasked with monitoring the disk space usage of a Linux server. Which command should they use to view the disk space used and available on all mounted filesystems?
questions.explanation:
df -h (disk free) displays the amount of disk space used and available on all mounted filesystems in a human-readable format. It is the appropriate command for monitoring overall disk space usage on a system.
Option B is incorrect.
du -sh (disk usage) shows the amount of disk space used by specific files and directories, not the overall disk space usage of all mounted filesystems.
Option C is incorrect.
fdisk -l lists the partitions on a disk, but it does not show the disk space usage of mounted filesystems.
Option D is incorrect.
mount is used to mount filesystems and view mounted filesystems, but it does not display disk space usage.

questions.question: A system administrator needs to find all occurrences of the word 'error' in a file named system.log. Which command should they use?
questions.explanation:
grep 'error' system.log is the correct command to search for all occurrences of the word error in the file system.log. grep is used for pattern matching and searching within files.
Option B is incorrect.
find system.log -name 'error' is incorrect, find is used for locating files in a directory hierarchy, not for searching within files.
Option C is incorrect.
While cat system.log | grep 'error' would work, it is unnecessary to use cat when grep can directly read the file.
Option D is incorrect.
echo 'error' > system.log would overwrite system.log with the word error instead of searching within it.

questions.question: A system administrator wants to continuously monitor the real-time system load and active processes of their Linux server. Which command will provide a dynamic, interactive view of this information?
questions.explanation:
top provides a dynamic, real-time view of the system's running processes, including CPU and memory usage, process IDs, and other vital system statistics. It is an interactive tool commonly used for monitoring system performance.
Option B is incorrect.
ps aux shows current running processes with detailed information, but it provides a static snapshot rather than a dynamic, real-time view.
Option C is incorrect.
vmstat reports information about processes, memory, paging, block IO, traps, and CPU activity, but it is not as interactive or comprehensive for process monitoring as top.
Option D is incorrect.
While htop is an alternative to top and provides a similar real-time view, it may not be installed by default on all Linux systems, making top the more universally applicable choice.

questions.question: A system administrator wants to view the current system's uptime and load averages. Which command should they use in a Linux environment?
questions.explanation:
The uptime command in Linux displays the current time, how long the system has been running, how many users are currently logged on, and the system load averages for the past 1, 5, and 15 minutes.
Option A is incorrect.
The df command is used to report file system disk space usage, not to check system uptime and load averages.
Option B is incorrect.
The free command shows the amount of free and used memory in the system, but it does not provide information about system uptime or load averages.
Option D is incorrect.
The ps command displays information about active processes. It does not provide information on system uptime or load averages.

questions.question: A user needs to change the permissions of a file named script.sh to make it executable. Which command should they use?
questions.explanation:
The chmod +x script.sh command changes the file permissions of script.sh to make it executable. chmod is used for changing file access permissions, and +x adds execute permissions.
Option B is incorrect.
chown is used to change file ownership, not to change file permissions.
Option C is incorrect.
mkdir is used to create directories, not to change file permissions.
Option D is incorrect.
cp is used to copy files and directories, not to change file permissions.

questions.question: A user needs to find the total size of a directory, including all its subdirectories and files. Which command should they use?\n\r
questions.explanation:
The command du -sh is used in Linux to display the total disk usage of a directory and its subdirectories in a human-readable format. The -s option provides a summary, and -h makes the output human-readable.
Option B is incorrect.
df -h displays disk space usage for file systems, not for a specific directory and its contents.
Option C is incorrect.
ls -lh lists files in the current directory in a human-readable format but does not provide the total size of the directory and its subdirectories.
Option D is incorrect.
chmod 755 changes file permissions and is not related to finding the size of directories.

questions.question: An administrator needs to check the current Linux kernel version running on their system. Which command will provide this information?
questions.explanation:
The uname -r command is specifically used to display the kernel release information of the Linux system. It is the most direct way to find out the kernel version.
Option B is incorrect.
lsb_release -a provides information about the Linux distribution but does not specifically display the kernel version.
Option C is incorrect.
While cat /proc/version does show kernel information, including the version, uname -r is more commonly used for this specific purpose.
Option D is incorrect.
ifconfig is used for displaying and configuring network interfaces and has no relation to displaying the kernel version.

questions.question: In a Linux environment, which command would you use to copy a file named 'data.txt' from your current directory to a directory named 'backup'?
questions.explanation:
The cp command is used to copy files or directories. Here, cp data.txt backup/ copies data.txt from the current directory to the backup directory.
Option B is incorrect.
mv moves or renames files or directories. It would move data.txt to the backup directory, not copy it.
Option C is incorrect.
rm is used to remove files or directories, which is not the intended action in this scenario.
Option D is incorrect.
ln is used to create links to files, not to copy them. ln data.txt backup/ would create a link to data.txt in the backup directory, not copy the file.

questions.question: In Linux, which command is used to display the manual page of a command?
questions.explanation:
man is used to display the manual pages of a command in Linux. It provides detailed information about command syntax, options, and usage.
Option A is incorrect.
ls is used to list directory contents, not to display the manual page of a command.
Option C is incorrect.
echo is used to display a line of text/string that is passed as an argument, not for displaying manual pages.
Option D is incorrect.
grep is used to search for a specified pattern within files, not to display the manual pages of commands.

questions.question: In order to view all currently running processes in a Linux system, which command should be used?
questions.explanation:
The ps aux command displays detailed information about all currently running processes, including those started by users and system processes.
Option B is incorrect.
top shows a real-time view of running processes, but it's more focused on processes consuming the most system resources rather than listing every process.
Option C is incorrect.
ifconfig is used for configuring and displaying network interface parameters, and it does not display information about running processes.
Option D is incorrect.
uname -a displays system information such as the kernel version and machine hardware name, but it does not list running processes.

questions.question: To check the disk usage of a specific directory /home/user/documents and display the result in a human-readable format, which command should a system administrator use?
questions.explanation:
du -sh /home/user/documents displays the disk usage of the specified directory in a human-readable format (e.g., KB, MB, GB). The -s option provides a summary (rather than listing each file), and -h makes the output human-readable.
Option A is incorrect.
df -h displays disk space usage for file systems, not for specific directories.
Option C is incorrect.
ls -lh lists the files in the specified directory with their sizes in a human-readable format, but it does not provide the total size of the directory.
Option D is incorrect.
fdisk -l lists the partitions on disks and does not provide disk usage information for specific directories.

questions.question: To concatenate and display the contents of multiple text files named file1.txt and file2.txt on the terminal, which command should a Linux user execute?
questions.explanation:
The cat (concatenate) command is used to display the contents of files, and it can concatenate multiple files. Here, cat file1.txt file2.txt will display the contents of both files in the order they are listed.
Option B is incorrect.
less is used for paging through text one screen at a time but does not concatenate files.
Option C is incorrect.
touch is used to create new empty files or update the timestamps of existing files, not to display or concatenate file contents.
Option D is incorrect.
mv is used to move or rename files, not for displaying or concatenating their contents.

questions.question: To concatenate two text files, report1.txt and report2.txt, into a new file named combined_report.txt, which command should be used in Linux?
questions.explanation:
The cat command, when used with the > operator, concatenates the contents of report1.txt and report2.txt and redirects the combined output into combined_report.txt.
Option B is incorrect.
mv is used to move or rename files, not to concatenate them.
Option C is incorrect.
cp is used to copy files and directories, but it does not concatenate file contents.
Option D is incorrect.
ls lists directory contents and cannot be used for concatenating files. The > operator redirects the output, but ls is not the correct command for this task.

questions.question: To display detailed information about the Linux distribution currently in use, including the version and codename, which command should be used?
questions.explanation:
The lsb_release -a command displays detailed information about the Linux distribution, including its version and codename. LSB stands for Linux Standard Base, which provides standardized information about a Linux system.
Option A is incorrect.
uname -a displays basic information about the system's kernel and architecture but does not provide detailed distribution information.
Option B is incorrect.
df -h shows the disk space usage of the file system and has nothing to do with the distribution information.
Option D is incorrect.
top provides real-time information about running processes and system resource usage but does not display information about the Linux distribution.

questions.question: To display the amount of free and used memory in the Linux system, which command should a system administrator use?
questions.explanation:
The free -m command displays the total amount of free and used physical and swap memory in the system in megabytes. It provides a quick overview of memory usage.
Option B is incorrect.
df -h displays the amount of disk space used and available on mounted file systems, not memory usage.
Option C is incorrect.
While top does display memory usage among other system information, free -m is specifically designed for a concise view of memory usage.
Option D is incorrect.
du -sh estimates file space usage, it does not provide information about memory usage.

questions.question: To display the current date and time in the Linux system, which command should a user execute?
questions.explanation:
The date command in Linux is used to display the current system date and time. It is the direct command for checking the current date and time.
Option B is incorrect.
cal displays a calendar of the current month, not the current date and time.
Option C is incorrect.
uptime shows how long the system has been running, the number of users, and the system load, but not the current date and time.
Option D is incorrect.
timedatectl is used to query and change the system clock and its settings but is more complex than necessary for simply displaying the current date and time.

questions.question: To display the disk usage of the file system in a human-readable format, which command should a Linux user execute?
questions.explanation:
The df -h command displays the amount of disk space used and available on Linux file systems in a human-readable format (e.g., in KB, MB, GB).
Option B is incorrect.
du -h displays the disk usage of files and directories, not the overall file system usage like df -h.
Option C is incorrect.
free -m shows the amount of free and used memory in the system, not disk space usage.
Option D is incorrect.
ifconfig is used for configuring network interfaces, and it is unrelated to disk space usage.

questions.question: To display the total amount of free and used physical and swap memory in the system, as well as the buffers used by the kernel, which command should a Linux user execute?
questions.explanation:
The free -m command is used to show the total amount of free and used physical and swap memory in the system in megabytes, along with the memory used by the kernel for buffers.
Option A is incorrect.
df -h shows the amount of disk space used and available on mounted file systems, not memory usage.
Option C is incorrect.
top provides a dynamic view of system processes and includes memory usage, but free -m is specifically designed to display memory information in a clear and concise format.
Option D is incorrect.
du -sh is used to estimate file space usage, it does not display memory usage information.

questions.question: To display the total, used, and free disk space on all mounted filesystems in a human-readable format, which command should a system administrator use?
questions.explanation:
df -h (disk free) is used to report the amount of disk space used and available on Linux file systems in a human-readable format. The -h option makes the output easy to read.
Option B is incorrect.
du -sh estimates file space usage for a specific directory or file, not the total disk space of all mounted filesystems.
Option C is incorrect.
free -m shows the amount of free and used memory in the system in megabytes, not disk space usage.
Option D is incorrect.
ls -lh lists files in the current directory in a human-readable format but does not show disk space usage of mounted filesystems.

questions.question: To find out how long the Linux system has been running, along with the average load, which command should be executed?
questions.explanation:
The uptime command shows how long the system has been running since the last boot, along with the load average over 1, 5, and 15 minutes.
Option B is incorrect.
last is used to display a list of last logged-in users, not system uptime or load average.
Option C is incorrect.
While top does show system uptime in its display, it's primarily used for monitoring real-time process activity, making uptime a more direct choice for this specific requirement.
Option D is incorrect.
date displays the current date and time, but it does not show system uptime or load average.

questions.question: To monitor the real-time performance of system processes and system resource usage, which command should a Linux system administrator use?
questions.explanation:
The top command is used for real-time monitoring of system processes and their resource usage, including CPU and memory. It provides a dynamic, constantly updated view of the running system.
Option A is incorrect.
ps aux displays information about currently running processes, but it does not provide real-time, continuously updated information like top.
Option B is incorrect.
ifconfig is used for displaying and configuring network interfaces, and it is unrelated to monitoring system processes or resource usage.
Option D is incorrect.
uname -a displays system information such as the kernel version and machine hardware name, but it does not provide real-time monitoring of system processes.

questions.question: To recursively list all files and directories in the current directory, including hidden ones, which command should be used in Linux?
questions.explanation:
The ls -la command lists all files and directories in the current directory, including hidden ones (those starting with a dot). The -l option provides detailed listings, and -a includes hidden files.
Option A is incorrect.
ls -l lists files and directories with detailed information, but it does not include hidden files.
Option B is incorrect.
ls -a lists all files including hidden ones, but it does not provide detailed listings.
Option D is incorrect.
ls -r lists files and directories in reverse order, it does not list all files or provide detailed listings.

questions.question: To redirect the standard output of a command to a file called log.txt, replacing any existing content in the file, which command syntax should a Linux system administrator use?
questions.explanation:
Using > in the command command > log.txt redirects the standard output of command to log.txt, replacing any existing content in the file. It's the correct way to overwrite a file with the output of a command.
Option B is incorrect.
command >> log.txt appends the output to log.txt without overwriting existing content.
Option C is incorrect.
command < log.txt uses log.txt as standard input to the command, not as output redirection.
Option D is incorrect.
command && log.txt is incorrect syntax for file redirection. && is a conditional operator used to execute log.txt as a command if command is successful, which is not the intended action.

questions.question: To schedule a command or script to run at a specific time and date, which command should a Linux user employ?
questions.explanation:
The at command in Linux is used to schedule commands or scripts to be executed at a specific future time and date. It is the appropriate tool for one-time task scheduling.
Option A is incorrect.
cron is used for scheduling repetitive tasks at regular intervals, not for a single occurrence in the future.
Option C is incorrect.
nohup is used to run a command immune to hangups, but it does not schedule tasks for future execution.
Option D is incorrect.
nice changes the priority of a process, not for scheduling it at a specific time.

questions.question: To search for a specific text string within a file named report.txt, which command should a Linux user utilize?
questions.explanation:
The grep command is used to search for specific text within files. In this case, grep 'search_string' report.txt will search for the occurrence of 'search_string' within the file report.txt.
Option B is incorrect.
find is used to locate files within a directory hierarchy but does not search for text within files.
Option C is incorrect.
cat report.txt | search_string is a syntactically incorrect command. The correct usage would involve grep to search within the output.
Option D is incorrect.
touch is used to create a new empty file or update an existing file's timestamps, not for searching text within a file.

questions.question: What command is used in Linux to list the contents of a directory?
questions.explanation:
ls is the standard command in Linux to list directory contents. It displays files, directories, and other items stored in a specific directory.
Option B is incorrect.
pwd (Print Working Directory) is used to display the current directory that the user is in, not to list the contents of a directory.
Option C is incorrect.
cd (Change Directory) is used to change the current directory to another directory, not to list directory contents.
Option D is incorrect.
mkdir (Make Directory) is used to create a new directory, not to list the contents of a directory.

questions.question: What does the chmod 755 filename command do?
answers: Sets permissions to rwx for owner, rx for group and others
questions.explanation: chmod 755 sets read, write, and execute for the owner, and read and execute for group and others. It does not hide files (prefix . does that), remove permissions, or change ownership (chown).

questions.question: What does the df -h command do?
answers: Displays filesystem disk usage in human-readable format
questions.explanation: df -h shows filesystem usage with readable units like GB/MB. free handles memory, top and ps show processes, and ss/netstat show network usage.

questions.question: Which command is used to display the disk usage of a directory in a human-readable format?
questions.explanation: du -sh shows the total disk usage of a directory in a summarized and human-readable format. ls -lh lists individual file sizes. df -h shows overall filesystem usage, and free -m is for memory stats.

questions.question: Which command lists all files, including hidden ones, in a directory?
questions.explanation: ls -a lists all files including hidden ones (those starting with .). ls without -a omits hidden files, find can find files but not list them traditionally, and tree shows hierarchy, not a simple file list.

questions.question: Which command provides real-time monitoring of CPU and memory usage?
questions.explanation: top provides a real-time, interactive display of CPU, memory, and processes. free shows memory usage statically, df is for disk, and ps shows process info at a single moment.

questions.question: Which command should a Linux user execute to display information about the CPU, including its type, make, model, and performance?
questions.explanation:
lscpu gathers CPU architecture information from sysfs and /proc/cpuinfo. The command displays information about the CPU architecture, including the number of CPUs, threads, cores, sockets, and more.
Option B is incorrect.
lsblk lists information about all available or specified block devices, which are related to storage devices, not CPU information.
Option C is incorrect.
ifconfig is used for configuring or displaying network interface parameters, not for displaying CPU information.
Option D is incorrect.
fdisk is a command-line utility to view and manage disk partitions, and it does not provide CPU-related information.

questions.question: Which command should a Linux user execute to view the currently logged-in users on the system?
questions.explanation:
The users command in Linux displays the usernames of users currently logged in to the current host. It provides a list of names, one per line.
Option B is incorrect.
ps aux displays information about currently running processes, including those started by all users, but it does not specifically list the users who are logged in.
Option C is incorrect.
free -m is used to show the amount of free and used memory in the system, and it is unrelated to user login information.
Option D is incorrect.
ifconfig is used for displaying and configuring network interfaces, and it does not provide information about logged-in users.

questions.question: Which command should a user run to check the amount of free and used memory in the Linux system?
questions.explanation:
The free -m command is used to display the amount of free and used memory in the system in megabytes. It provides a quick overview of memory usage including total, used, free, shared, buffer/cache, and available memory.
Option A is incorrect.
df -h (disk free) displays the amount of disk space used and available on Linux file systems, not memory usage.
Option C is incorrect.
While top does provide memory usage information among other details, it is primarily used for dynamic real-time monitoring of system processes, and free -m is more specific for checking memory usage.
Option D is incorrect.
du -sh (disk usage) shows the amount of disk space used by the specified files and directories, but it does not provide information on memory usage.

questions.question: You need to view the contents of a text file named 'report.txt' in a Linux environment without editing it. Which command would you use?
questions.explanation:
The cat command is used to display the contents of a file. In this scenario, cat report.txt will display the contents of report.txt without editing it.
Option A is incorrect.
The touch command is used to create a new empty file or update the timestamp of an existing file, not for viewing file contents.
Option C is incorrect.
The mv command is used for moving or renaming files and directories, not for viewing file contents.
Option D is incorrect.
The chmod command changes the file permissions, but it does not display file contents.
